metadata.title: Preparation of hexagonal ultrathin WO3 nano-ribbons and their electrochemical performance as an anode material in lithium ion batteries

sections.text:
Received: 24 July 2015 Revised: 10 October 2015 Accepted: 14 October 2015 © Tsinghua University Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2015 KEYWORDS hexagonal tungsten oxide, ultrathin nano-ribbons, low-dimensional structure, anode material, lithium ion battery
＿
20) crystal plane. The HUWNRs exhibit good electrochemical performance as an anode material in lithium ion batteries because of their unique structure. It is believed that these unique materials may be applied in many fields.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Ultrathin one-dimensional nanomaterials have attracted considerable attention due to their unique physical and chemical properties [1–4]. Tungsten oxide is a nontoxic and environmentally benign material that is widely applied in electrochromic devices, gas sensors,
optical devices, and catalysts [5–9]. In the past few years, much research effort has focused on the development of strategies for the fabrication of one-dimensional tungsten oxide materials. For example, Xi et al. reported a simple one-pot solution-phase method to prepare W18O49 bundles of individual 0.9 nm thick nanowires [10]. Also,
Address correspondence to cchen@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn
| www.editorialmanager.com/nare/default.asp
Ackermann et al. developed an alcohol-assisted solvothermal method to prepare size-tunable ultrathin W18O49 nanowires at the gram scale [11]. Furthermore, Wang et al. synthesized ultrathin WO2.73 nano-belts of subnanometer thickness via a facile one-pot solvothermal method [12]. However, the ultrathin onedimensional tungsten oxide materials prepared by these synthetic technologies are non-stoichiometric monoclinic tungsten oxides. Reliable preparation strategies for ultrathin one-dimensional tungsten oxide with stoichiometric compositions and crystalline phases other than monoclinic are still to be developed.
Tungsten trioxide has numerous crystalline polymorphs, such as monoclinic, triclinic, orthorhombic, tetragonal, cubic, and hexagonal phases. Metastable hexagonal phase WO3 is composed of layers containing distorted corner-sharing WO6 octahedra that arrange to form six-membered rings, and the layers are stacked along the [00l] axis to form open one-dimensional tunnels. This structure is different from the wellknown ReO3-related stable phases [13]. The layered WO3 crystal structure may serve as an intercalation host to accommodate Li+ ions to produce LixWO3, and is therefore a promising material for anodes in lithium ion batteries [13–17].
In this work, hexagonal ultrathin WO3 nano-ribbons (HUWNRs) of subnanometer thickness were synthesized by a solvothermal method. The HUWNRs, which mainly expose the (1 ＿
20) crystal plane, grow along the [001] direction. The as-prepared HUWNRs exhibit good electrochemical performance as an anode material in lithium ion batteries because of their unique structure.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials
sections.text: H2WO4 and oleic acid were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Oleylamine was purchased from J&K Chemical Ltd. (China). Other reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2 Characterization of the HUWNRs
sections.text:
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy
(HRTEM) images were taken on an FEI Tecnai G2F20 transmission electron microscope working at 200 kV. Crystalline structure and phase purity were determined by a Bruker D8-advance X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu K radiation ( = 1.5406 Å) at an accelerating potential of 40 kV and a tube current of 40 mA. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. Raman spectra were obtained using a PerkinElmer RamanStation 400 spectrometer with a 785 nm laser as the excitation source. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were made with a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al X-ray source. The binding energy scales for the samples were referenced by setting the C 1s binding energy of contamination carbon to 284.8 eV.

sections.heading: 2.3 Preparation of the HUWNRs
sections.text: In a typical experiment, H2WO4 (2 g), oleic acid (15 mL), and oleylamine (25 mL) were placed in a 100 mL Teflonlined autoclave, which was sealed and maintained at 180 °C for 72 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the products were collected from the bottom of the vessel by decanting. The blue product was dispersed in hexane and centrifuged at 6,000 rpm for 5 min to remove any undispersed residue. The products were further purified with an ethanol-cyclohexane (1:9) mixture by dispersing and centrifugation at 6,000 rpm, and then washed with acetic acid and ethanol separately. The obtained HUWNRs were then dried at 80 °C.

sections.heading: 2.4 Electrochemical measurement
sections.text:
Before electrochemical measurement, the HUWNRs were calcined at 200 °C for 12 h in air to remove any organic substrates adsorbed. They were then treated with a slurry coating procedure. The slurry was made by mixing 80 wt.% active materials, 10 wt.% carbon black, and 10 wt.% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl pyrrolidinone (NMP). The mass of the active materials is about 3 mg. The slurry was then spread uniformly on a copper foil current collector (Φ 10 mm) and dried under vacuum at 120 °C overnight. Then, 2016-type coin cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glove box using Li foil as the counter electrode.
www.theNanoResearch.com∣www.Springer.com/journal/12274 | Nano Research
Galvanostatic charge–discharge cycling was performed between 0.005 and 3.0 V (vs. Li/Li+) using an automatic galvanostat (NEWARE) at a current density of 50 mA·g−1 at room temperature. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) were performed on a PGSTAT 302N, Metrohm-Autolab instrument.

sections.heading: 3 Results and discussion
sections.text:
The morphology of the prepared HUWNRs is shown in Fig. 1. The product bundles are composed of nanoribbons with widths of 2–5 nm and lengths of up to several micrometers (Figs. 1(a) and 1(b)). From the image of the stacks, the thickness of the as-prepared HUWNR is estimated to be below 1 nm (Fig. 1(b)). Twisted HUWNRs and bent HUWNR with continuous crystal lattice stripes can be further observed in the HRTEM images (Figs. 1(c) and 1(d)), which indicates that the HUWNRs were highly flexible. The inter-fringe distances of the two orthogonal directions on the face of the HUWNRs are measured to be 0.38 and 0.63 nm, respectively, which are close to the lattice spacings in the (002) and (100) crystal planes, respectively, of hexagonal WO3. Applying both crystallographic and structural chemistry knowledge, we propose that the main exposed facet of the HUWNRs is the (1 ＿
20) crystal plane.
As shown in Fig. 2(a), the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the HUWNRs matches well with that of hexagonal WO3 (JCPDS #85-2459). The specific crystal growth direction of the as-prepared HUWNRs leads to the different relative strengths of diffraction peaks compared with the standard diffraction signals of hexagonal WO3. The nano-ribbon structure exhibits low long-range order in the (100) and (1 ＿
20) crystal planes, and high long-range order in the (002) crystal plane; therefore weaker (100) and (1 ＿
20) peaks, and stronger (002) diffraction peaks, are observed, which is in agreement with the HRTEM results.
The Raman spectrum of HUWNRs is typical of hexagonal WO3 (Fig. 2(b)) [18–21]. The bands at 240 and 324 cm−1 are related to the W–O–W bending modes, while the bands at 712 and 760 cm−1 are related to O–W–O stretching modes. The band at 435 cm−1 is characteristic of crystalline WO3, and the band at 952 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching mode of terminal W=O double bonds on the boundaries of the nanocrystals.
Figure 2(c) shows the FT-IR spectrum of the HUWNRs. It is evident that there are some organic molecules, such as oleic acid and oleylamine, adsorbed on their surface. Aside from the absorptions of the organic molecules, strong absorption bands for the W–O–W  stretching modes at 600–1,000 nm−1 can be clearly observed [22, 23].
| www.editorialmanager.com/nare/default.asp
The valence states of tungsten were measured using XPS (Fig. 2(d)). The peaks at binding energies of 35.2 and 37.4 eV correspond to the W4f7/2 and W4f5/2 transitions of W6+, while the peaks at binding energies of 33.8 and 36.2 eV correspond to those of W5+ [21, 24]. The measured proportion of W5+ atoms is only 0.8%. It is worth noting that the product with one-dimensional morphology (Fig. S1 in the Electronic Supplementary Material (ESM)) after the solvothermal process is blue (the color of non-stoichiometric WO3−x-type tungsten oxides), but then turns to yellow green during the washing process. Thus, we propose that WO3−x nanowires are prepared under solvothermal conditions and the products are then oxidized and purified to HUWNRs in the washing and purification process.
Currently, transition metal oxides such as cobalt oxide, iron oxide, and tungsten oxide are attracting increasing attention as anode materials due to their
much higher specific capacity than commercial graphite anodes [25–27]. It has been demonstrated that the control of particle size and morphology at the nanometer scale is a feasible approach to improve the electrochemical performance of transition metal oxides [27, 28]. It is believed that nanomaterials prepared with the correct choice of size and morphology are able to expand much more easily and better accommodate the structural strain of the electrochemical reaction of lithium. This results in the improvement of electrochemical performance [28, 29].
The electrochemical performance of the HUWNRs was tested by charging/discharging the cell at a constant current of 50 mA·g−1 between 0.005 and 3.0 V vs. Li/Li+. In the CV analysis of the as-prepared HUWNRs in the first cycle between 0.005 and 3.0 V (Fig. S4 in the ESM), the two cathodic peaks of lithium in the HUWNRs electrode are observed at 2.5 and 1.5 V vs. Li+/Li–, which can be attributed to the irreversible reactions that
www.theNanoResearch.com∣www.Springer.com/journal/12274 | Nano Research
from the impurities on the surface of the nanocrystals. Meanwhile, two inconspicuous broad anodic peaks are also presented, which is consistent with previous reports [30–32].
Figures 3(a) and 3(b) show the electrochemical performance of HUWNRs as an anode material in a lithium ion battery. Figure 3(a) shows the capacity stability over 50 cycles. It can be seen that the WO3 electrode delivers a discharge capacity of ca. 816 mA·h·g−1 in a cut-off range between 0.005 and 3.0 V in the first cycle at a current density of 50 mA·g−1. After the first cycle, the discharge capacity decreases rapidly and the WO3 electrode exhibits good cycle stability from the
beginning of the second charge–discharge cycle. This can be ascribed to the structure changes during the initial charge–discharge process. The current efficiency remains above 99% during the next cycle process. The WO3 electrode delivers a discharge capacity of ca. 152 mA·h·g−1 after 50 cycles, and the capacity retention is about 87.3%, which is better than that of the WO3 nanowires (75%) displayed [17].
It is noteworthy that the HUWNRs in our work mainly expose the (1 ＿
20) crystal plane, which contains a layered arrangement of W6+ (Fig. 3(d)). This specific structure is favorable for the electrochemical reaction of lithium, which directly improves the electrochemical
| www.editorialmanager.com/nare/default.asp
reaction efficiency. In addition, the open hexagonal tunnels of the WO3 structure in the HUWNRs are parallel to the growth direction of the nano-ribbons, i.e., the c-axis, which is perpendicular to the (002) crystal plane (Figs. 3(e)–3(f)), facilitating the diffusion of Li+. The ultrathin thickness of HUWNRs also reduces the Li+ diffusion distance. The low resistance for Li+ diffusion may be the most important reason for the enhanced cycling capability of the electrode.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
A solvothermal method was developed to prepare HUWNRs with widths of 2–5 nm, thicknesses of less than 1 nm, and lengths of up to several micrometers. The HUWNRs, which grow in the [001] direction, mainly expose the (1 ＿
20) crystal plane. The specific structure of the HUWNRs endows this material with good electrochemical performance as an anode material in lithium ion batteries. We expect that hexagonal WO3 with this unique structure may find application in many fields.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text:
This work was supported by the State Key Project of Fundamental Research for Nanoscience and Nanotechnology (Nos. 2011CB932401, 2011CBA00500, and 2012CB224802), and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 21221062, 21131004, and 21390393). The authors thank Electron Microscopy Laboratory of Peking University for the help with HRTEM analysis.
Electronic Supplementary Material: Supplementary material (TEM image of the tungsten oxides products after the solvothermal process; TEM image and XRD pattern of the HUWNRs after calcination at 200 °C for 12 h) is available in the online version of this article at http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s12274-015-0924-6.
